results.abstract: Despite the continued shutdown of the city’s movie houses, indie theaters just may survive: They are less reliant on Hollywood and have a loyal audience.
results.title: How New York’s Small Cinemas Are Hanging On

multimedia.caption: Nick Nicolaou, who owns Cinema Village, and the people behind indie cinemas like Film Forum, Anthology Film Archives and Nitehawk remain in an uneasy limbo, desperate for audiences yet terrified of cinemas becoming petri dishes.

results.title: Chills, Thrills and Challenging Films: Here Are 10 to Stream
results.abstract: In this spooky season, why not go out on a limb with these films off the beaten path? If you’re not up for creature features, we still have you covered.

des_facet: Le Bleu Blanc Rouge De Mes Cheveux (Movie)
results.title: Black Women’s Hair and Horror Movies: What Could Go Wrong?
results.abstract: An evil weave turns a shy character into a serial killer in “Bad Hair,” but the film doesn’t understand that styling locks can be a source of intimacy and communal pride.

results.title: Phillipa Soo’s Week: Fund-Raising Videos and ‘Agents of Chaos’
results.abstract: As Broadway remains on pause, the former “Hamilton” star voices a mythical goddess in Netflix’s “Over the Moon” and is lending her support to causes she believes in.
(Or vice versa.) It’s Halloween week and treats abound, from oysters to ballet to a Sam Smith concert.
results.title: Hail the Supermoon And Howl at a Canine Costume Contest

results.title: ‘Now and Then’ at 25: Girlhood Finally Taken Seriously
results.abstract: This movie about inseparable tweens and the grown-ups they became was dismissed in 1995. Today it’s cherished by waves of new fans for the weight it gives their stories.

results.abstract: Michael Powell’s disturbing chronicle of a murderous filmmaker was ahead of its time, influencing Martin Scorsese, Brian De Palma and Kathryn Bigelow.
results.title: Want a Halloween Thriller as Daring as ‘Psycho’? Try ‘Peeping Tom’

results.abstract: Frightening movies help fans gain a “new understanding,” says the veteran star of scary stories, including the new “Tales From the Hood 3.”
results.title: Tony Todd on the Joy of ‘Candyman,’ and the Role of Black Horror

multimedia.copyright: Clifford Prince King for The New York Times
multimedia.caption: Despite his extensive theater background, Todd is known for horror movies, but he doesn’t mind: The genre is “passionately adored — so I don’t see it as a secondhand citizenship.”
